facts.text: Respondent was a booking clerk at Saharanpur railway station in 1955-56.
Between October 22, 1955, and May 26, 1956, respondent committed criminal breach of trust in respect of Rs. 49/1/0.
Accused sent up for trial before Special Judge West, Lucknow, for offences under s.5(1)(c) read with s.5(2) of Prevention of Corruption Act No. II of 1947.
Prosecution filed 124 documents and examined 20 witnesses before Special Judge.
Accused admitted realizing the amounts as alleged but pleaded no dishonest intention; deficit due to inadvertence and oversight.
Special Judge considered evidence, found prosecution established misappropriation, convicted accused under s.5(2) and sentenced to one year's rigorous imprisonment.
Investigation conducted by Sub-Inspector Mathur, who was below rank of Deputy Superintendent of Police.

On April 26, 1956, A.N. Khanna, Railway Sectional Officer, Special Police Establishment, sent report to Superintendent of Police, SPE, Lucknow, about information received that accused habitually misappropriated money, giving 7 instances.
Superintendent directed Sub-Inspector Mathur to make enquiry; Mathur checked railway records after permission from Station Master, found information correct, submitted report.
On October 8, 1956, Sub-Inspector Mathur applied to Additional District Magistrate (Judicial), Lucknow, for permission to investigate.
On October 19, 1956, Magistrate permitted Sub-Inspector to investigate.
After permission, Sub-Inspector made further investigation, seized documents, took statements, submitted charge-sheet.

Allahabad High Court, Lucknow Bench, in Criminal Appeal No. 643 of 1960, dated January 30, 1960, set aside conviction, holding Sub-Inspector investigated before permission, violating Act, causing prejudice to accused.
High Court observed prosecution had not eliminated reasonable possibility of defence being correct.
Defence examined 3 witnesses before Special Judge.

legal_issues.text: Whether the investigation made by Sub-Inspector Mathur before obtaining permission under s.5A of the Prevention of Corruption Act vitiated the entire trial.
Whether the accused was prejudiced by any irregularity in the investigation.
Whether the preliminary enquiry by Sub-Inspector constituted 'investigation' under CrPC.

petitioner_arguments.text: Sub-Inspector only made preliminary enquiry to ascertain truth of information, not full investigation; after permission, proper investigation conducted.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.5A Prevention of Corruption Act; definition of investigation under s.4(1) CrPC

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if irregularity, High Court erred in setting aside conviction without considering if accused prejudiced; s.537 CrPC applies.

respondent_arguments.text: Investigation made in consistent disregard of safeguards under s.5A; prejudice to accused must be presumed without further proof.

court_reasoning.text: Sub-Inspector's actions before permission (checking records, verifying info, submitting report) constituted investigation under s.4(1) CrPC as per H.N. Rishbud.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Information was precise; steps taken were ascertainment of facts, proceeding to spot.

court_reasoning.text: s.5A mandatory, safeguards for public servants; but violation does not automatically vitiate trial unless prejudice shown.
court_reasoning.key_observation: After permission, fresh investigation conducted; no defects thereafter.

court_reasoning.text: No prejudice to accused: fair trial, 20 prosecution witnesses, 124 exhibits, defence examined 3 witnesses, Special Judge found guilt proved.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.537 CrPC requires nexus between irregularity and prejudice; none here.

court_reasoning.text: Mudholkar J. (separate): Preliminary enquiries to verify info not 'investigation'; no harassment, s.5A not violated.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Investigation involves collection of evidence for trial; mere checking records short of that.

holdings.text: Preliminary actions by Sub-Inspector constituted investigation, violating s.5A, but no prejudice caused; trial not vitiated.
Under s.537 CrPC, irregularity in investigation does not vitiate trial unless prejudice to accused.
Conviction under s.5(2) Prevention of Corruption Act restored.

precedents_cited.case_name: H.N. Rishbud and Inder Singh v. The State of Delhi
precedents_cited.relevance: Defined 'investigation' under CrPC Ch. XIV, listing steps including ascertainment of facts, collection of evidence.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madhya Pradesh v. Mubarak Ali
precedents_cited.relevance: Explained purpose of s.5A as safeguard against harassment of public servants.
Informal enquiry on vague telegram not investigation.
Described stages before formal investigation starts.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Kerala v. M.J. Samuel
precedents_cited.relevance: Not every vague info is FIR; depends on facts.

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Offence of criminal misconduct; prior permission required for investigation by officer below DSP rank.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of investigation; procedure; irregularities not vitiating trial unless prejudice.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences requiring permission under s.5A of Act.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the State's appeal, set aside High Court's acquittal, restored Special Judge's conviction and sentence of one year's rigorous imprisonment under s.5(2) of Prevention of Corruption Act.

key_quotes.text: "the statutory safeguards must be strictly complied with, for they were conceived in public interest and were provided as a guarantee against frivolous and vexatious prosecution."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "there must be a sufficient nexus, either established or probabilized, between the conviction and the irregularity in the investigation."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Test for prejudice under s.537 CrPC.

key_quotes.text: "Merely making some preliminary enquiries upon receipt of information from an anonymous source or a source of doubtful reliability for checking up the correctness of the information does not amount to collection of evidence."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Mudholkar J. on what is not investigation.
